ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Twenty Yawns, we practiced counting to 20.

In this activity, we will complete a number scavenger hunt. Sometimes I will ask you to find a certain number of objects. Other times, I will ask you to find one object with a certain number of parts. You will work with a partner to search the classroom and bring back the correct number of objects. Then we will count them to check.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Search Pair children with partners. Give all partners the same number of objects to find: Find three books. Guide partners to search the classroom to find the objects and then return to the small group.
Count Have each partner count the objects they found. Guide children to point to each object as they count it aloud.

Repeat Repeat the activity, this time asking for an object with a certain number of parts: Find something that has two eyes. Have partners search the classroom and bring back an object fitting that description. Have children point to each part of the object as they count aloud. Repeat as time allows.

Talk About Counting Talk about searching for and counting objects. Was it easier to find a certain number of objects, or to find something with a certain number of parts? What made each type of hunt easy or hard?

Start by only asking for a certain number of objects, and move to parts as children are ready. Always ask for a number of objects less than five. Model searching the classroom for the first object requested, thinking aloud as you count.

Invite children to choose the object or part of an object that the group should hunt for. Challenge children to describe the objects they find in complete sentences: This is one doll. It has two eyes.

Hold up a Numeral Card to show how many of each object you are requesting. Use hand gestures or hold up an example of the object you are requesting to assist in children’s understanding of vocabulary. Pair multilingual learners with partners who speak the same home language, if possible.

Repeat your directions as children search to help them stay on task. For example, I can’t wait to see what you’ll find that has two eyes! You may also wish to assign partners to specific sections of the classroom to search in.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need a file folder to serve as a “curtain” and 10 Connecting Cubes for each child and yourself.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Twenty Yawns, we talked about how characters used their memory to solve problems.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the words memory and remember. Use the memory and remember Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, I will show you a certain number of Connecting Cubes. Then, I will put the cubes “behind the curtain.” You will use your memory to remember how many Connecting Cubes there are, and then count out the same number of cubes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show Place two Connecting Cubes from your set of 10 onto the table. Give children a few moments to look at the cubes you placed.

Close the Curtain Hold up the file folder as a “curtain” so that children can no longer see your two Connecting Cubes. Ask, How many Connecting Cubes are behind the curtain? Count out the same number of cubes from your pile.

Count and Check Check that children count out two Connecting Cubes from their set of 10. Once all children have separated two cubes, lift the “curtain.” Ask children to check that they have the same amount by counting your cubes and then their cubes.
Repeat Continue the activity by placing different numbers of Connecting Cubes “behind the curtain” as time allows.
Talk About Memory Talk about how the children used their memories to complete the task. How did you use your memory in this activity?

Start out with five Connecting Cubes instead of 10. Count your Connecting Cubes aloud before you place them “behind the curtain,” and encourage children to count them with you to help strengthen their memory.
Vary the color and pattern of Connecting Cubes you place “behind the curtain.” Challenge children to match the number and colors of the Connecting Cubes you hid.
Review key vocabulary, such as count , how many, and same. Invite children to point to a Numeral Card that shows how many Connecting Cubes they counted.
Instead of counting out the Connecting Cubes, connect them together while counting aloud. Encourage children to manipulate the cubes so that they are connected in the same way as yours.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk: When we read Twenty Yawns, we talked about how long it takes to do different activities.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word long. Use the long Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: I will show you a picture of an activity. You will tell me if the activity takes a long time or a short time.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show children the first Activity Card. Describe the activity and ask if it would take a long time or a short time to complete. Challenge children to explain why they think that activity would take a long or short time.

Extend Ask children to describe another activity that takes longer or shorter than the activity. Encourage children to use complete sentences. For example: Going on a hike would take longer than going for a walk down the street because I’d walk for a long time.

Repeat Continue the activity until all Activity Cards have been shown. Encourage children to compare the lengths of activities between Activity Cards as well. For example: Does sliding down a slide take longer than blowing a bubble?
Talk About Time Discuss the lengths of the different activities. How could you tell which activities took longer? How does it feel when an activity takes a long time?
Model deciding how long an activity takes: I think pouring a bowl of cereal takes a short time. The cereal comes out of the box quickly, and the bowl is small!
Challenge children to order the Activity Cards from shortest to longest amount of time it takes to complete the activities.

Review that the suffix -er means more. Also, explain that the phrase takes [a long] time is an idiom, so it cannot be translated verbatim to another language. Explain that the phrase takes time in English means uses an amount of time to do something.

Build on children’s speech by extending their sentences to use greater detail. For example, if a child says, A bike ride is long, repeat back, Yes, riding a bike would take a long time because you might go to many places. Encourage children to repeat some of the phrases you add to practice more complex sentence structure.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Daytime/Nighttime, we discussed different things that happen during the day and at night.

In this activity, I will show you a picture of something you might see or do during the day or at night. You will decide whether the picture shows day or night and explain how you can tell. Then we will count things we see in the picture.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show children the first Activity Card. Describe what is in the picture, and ask whether the activity, animal, or sight is something that belongs during the day or at night. Challenge children to explain how they can tell whether the picture shows day or night.
Extend Invite children to count items in the picture. For example, children could count the number of people or trees in the picture, or how many toes a rooster has.

Repeat Continue the activity until all Activity Cards have been shown. For each picture, encourage children to say how they can tell whether the picture shows day or night and to count items they see.

Sort Guide children to sort the Activity Cards into two categories: day and night. Encourage them to place the cards in each category, one above the other, so that they create a simple bar graph. Ask children, How many cards show day? How many show night? Are there more cards that show day or night? How can you tell?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: The pictures in this activity matched what we read in Daytime/Nighttime. How did your memory help you know whether the cards show daytime or nighttime?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model deciding whether a picture shows day or night, thinking aloud: This card shows someone fishing. I would want to see what I was catching if I went fishing! I would fish during the day. I can see that the sun is out in this picture, so I know it is daytime.
Challenge children to sort the Activity Cards first by day and night, and then by whether they show country or city. Encourage them to use their memory of Daytime/Nighttime to sort.

Review key vocabulary, such as day, night, picture, and how many. Children may have varying experiences with the activities and animals shown in the cards. Describe what each picture shows, and use hand gestures as support.
Invite children to act out the activities, animals, and sights in each card. They can crow like roosters, hold their hands out to warm by a campfire, or pretend to look at city lights at night.
